â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : git: Recursive clones RCE 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   2.45.1, 2.44.1, 2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and 2.39.4,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repositories with submodules can be crafted in a way that
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   exploits a bug in Git whereby it can be fooled into writing
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   files not into the submodule's worktree but into a `.git/`
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   directory. This allows writing a hook that will be executed
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   while the clone operation is still running, giving the user
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   no opportunity to inspect the code that is being executed.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   The problem has been patched in versions 2.45.1, 2.44.1,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and 2.39.4. If symbolic link
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    support is disabled in Git (e.g. via `git config --global
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   core.symlinks false`), the described attack won't work. As
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   always, it is best to avoid cloning repositories from
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   untrusted sources.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : git: insecure hardlinks 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   2.45.1, 2.44.1, 2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and 2.39.4,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   local clones may end up hardlinking files into the target
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repository's object database when source and target
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repository reside on the same disk. If the source repository
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    is owned by a different user, then those hardlinked files
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   may be rewritten at any point in time by the untrusted user.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    Cloning local repositories will cause Git to either copy or
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    hardlink files of the source repository into the target
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repository. This significantly speeds up such local clones
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   compared to doing a "proper" clone and saves both disk space
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    and compute time. When cloning a repository located on the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   same disk that is owned by a different user than the current
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    user we also end up creating such hardlinks. These files
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   will continue to be owned and controlled by the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   potentially-untrusted user and can be rewritten by them at
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   will in the future. The problem has been patched in versions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    2.45.1, 2.44.1, 2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   2.39.4.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : git: symlink bypass 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   2.45.1, 2.44.1, 2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and 2.39.4,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   when cloning a local source repository that contains
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   symlinks via the filesystem, Git may create hardlinks to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary user-readable files on the same filesystem as the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   target repository in the `objects/` directory. Cloning a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   local repository over the filesystem may creating hardlinks
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   to arbitrary user-owned files on the same filesystem in the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   target Git repository's `objects/` directory. When cloning a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    repository over the filesystem (without explicitly
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   specifying the `file://` protocol or `--no-local`), the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   optimizations for local cloning
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   will be used, which include attempting to hard link the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   object files instead of copying them. While the code
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   includes checks against symbolic links in the source
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repository, which were added during the fix for
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   CVE-2022-39253, these checks can still be raced because the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   hard link operation ultimately follows symlinks. If the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   object on the filesystem appears as a file during the check,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    and then a symlink during the operation, this will allow
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   the adversary to bypass the check and create hardlinks in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   the destination objects directory to arbitrary,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   user-readable files. The problem has been patched in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   versions 2.45.1, 2.44.1, 2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    2.39.4.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : git: additional local RCE 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Git is a revision control system. The Git project
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   recommends to avoid working in untrusted repositories, and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   instead to clone it first with `git clone --no-local` to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   obtain a clean copy. Git has specific protections to make
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   that a safe operation even with an untrusted source
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repository, but vulnerabilities allow those protections to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   be bypassed. In the context of cloning local repositories
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   owned by other users, this vulnerability has been covered in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    CVE-2024-32004. But there are circumstances where the fixes
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    for CVE-2024-32004 are not enough: For example, when
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   obtaining a `.zip` file containing a full copy of a Git
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repository, it should not be trusted by default to be safe,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   as e.g. hooks could be configured to run within the context
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   of that repository. The problem has been patched in versions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    2.45.1, 2.44.1, 2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and 2.39.4.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    As a workaround, avoid using Git in repositories that have
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   been obtained via archives from untrusted sources.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : git: Recursive clones RCE 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   2.45.1, 2.44.1, 2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and 2.39.4,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repositories with submodules can be crafted in a way that
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   exploits a bug in Git whereby it can be fooled into writing
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   files not into the submodule's worktree but into a `.git/`
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   directory. This allows writing a hook that will be executed
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   while the clone operation is still running, giving the user
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   no opportunity to inspect the code that is being executed.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   The problem has been patched in versions 2.45.1, 2.44.1,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and 2.39.4. If symbolic link
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    support is disabled in Git (e.g. via `git config --global
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   core.symlinks false`), the described attack won't work. As
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   always, it is best to avoid cloning repositories from
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   untrusted sources.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : git: insecure hardlinks 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   2.45.1, 2.44.1, 2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and 2.39.4,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   local clones may end up hardlinking files into the target
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repository's object database when source and target
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repository reside on the same disk. If the source repository
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    is owned by a different user, then those hardlinked files
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   may be rewritten at any point in time by the untrusted user.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    Cloning local repositories will cause Git to either copy or
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    hardlink files of the source repository into the target
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repository. This significantly speeds up such local clones
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   compared to doing a "proper" clone and saves both disk space
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    and compute time. When cloning a repository located on the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   same disk that is owned by a different user than the current
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    user we also end up creating such hardlinks. These files
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   will continue to be owned and controlled by the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   potentially-untrusted user and can be rewritten by them at
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   will in the future. The problem has been patched in versions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    2.45.1, 2.44.1, 2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   2.39.4.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : git: symlink bypass 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   2.45.1, 2.44.1, 2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and 2.39.4,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   when cloning a local source repository that contains
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   symlinks via the filesystem, Git may create hardlinks to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary user-readable files on the same filesystem as the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   target repository in the `objects/` directory. Cloning a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   local repository over the filesystem may creating hardlinks
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   to arbitrary user-owned files on the same filesystem in the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   target Git repository's `objects/` directory. When cloning a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    repository over the filesystem (without explicitly
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   specifying the `file://` protocol or `--no-local`), the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   optimizations for local cloning
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   will be used, which include attempting to hard link the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   object files instead of copying them. While the code
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   includes checks against symbolic links in the source
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repository, which were added during the fix for
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   CVE-2022-39253, these checks can still be raced because the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   hard link operation ultimately follows symlinks. If the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   object on the filesystem appears as a file during the check,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    and then a symlink during the operation, this will allow
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   the adversary to bypass the check and create hardlinks in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   the destination objects directory to arbitrary,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   user-readable files. The problem has been patched in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   versions 2.45.1, 2.44.1, 2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    2.39.4.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : git: additional local RCE 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Git is a revision control system. The Git project
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   recommends to avoid working in untrusted repositories, and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   instead to clone it first with `git clone --no-local` to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   obtain a clean copy. Git has specific protections to make
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   that a safe operation even with an untrusted source
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repository, but vulnerabilities allow those protections to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   be bypassed. In the context of cloning local repositories
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   owned by other users, this vulnerability has been covered in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    CVE-2024-32004. But there are circumstances where the fixes
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    for CVE-2024-32004 are not enough: For example, when
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   obtaining a `.zip` file containing a full copy of a Git
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   repository, it should not be trusted by default to be safe,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   as e.g. hooks could be configured to run within the context
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   of that repository. The problem has been patched in versions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    2.45.1, 2.44.1, 2.43.4, 2.42.2, 2.41.1, 2.40.2, and 2.39.4.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    As a workaround, avoid using Git in repositories that have
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   been obtained via archives from untrusted sources.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : python: Parsing errors in email/_parseaddr.py lead to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   incorrect value in email address part of tuple 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : The email module of Python through 3.11.3 incorrectly
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   parses e-mail addresses that contain a special character.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   The wrong portion of an RFC2822 header is identified as the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   value of the addr-spec. In some applications, an attacker
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   can bypass a protection mechanism in which application
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   access is granted only after verifying receipt of e-mail to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   a specific domain (e.g., only @company.example.com addresses
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    may be used for signup). This occurs in email/_parseaddr.py
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    in recent versions of Python.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   incorrect value in email address part of tuple 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : The email module of Python through 3.11.3 incorrectly
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   parses e-mail addresses that contain a special character.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   The wrong portion of an RFC2822 header is identified as the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   value of the addr-spec. In some applications, an attacker
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   can bypass a protection mechanism in which application
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   access is granted only after verifying receipt of e-mail to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   a specific domain (e.g., only @company.example.com addresses
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    may be used for signup). This occurs in email/_parseaddr.py
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    in recent versions of Python.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : The Diffie-Hellman Key Agreement Protocol allows use of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    long exponents that arguably make certain calculations
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   unnecessarily expensive, because the 1996 van Oorschot and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Wiener paper found that "(appropriately) short exponents"
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   can be used when there are adequate subgroup constraints,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   and these short exponents can lead to less expensive
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   calculations than for long exponents. This issue is
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   different from CVE-2002-20001 because it is based on an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   observation about exponent size, rather than an observation
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   about numbers that are not public keys. The specific
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   situations in which calculation expense would constitute a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   server-side vulnerability depend on the protocol (e.g., TLS,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    SSH, or IKE) and the DHE implementation details. In
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   general, there might be an availability concern because of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   server-side resource consumption from DHE
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   modular-exponentiation calculations. Finally, it is possible
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    for an attacker to exploit this vulnerability and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   CVE-2002-20001 together.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : openssl: Unbounded memory growth with session handling
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   in TLSv1.3 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Issue summary: Some non-default TLS server
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   configurations can cause unbounded
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   memory growth when processing TLSv1.3 sessions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Impact summary: An attacker may exploit certain server
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   configurations to trigger
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   unbounded memory growth that would lead to a Denial of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Service
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   This problem can occur in TLSv1.3 if the non-default
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   SSL_OP_NO_TICKET option is
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   being used (but not if early_data support is also configured
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    and the default
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   anti-replay protection is in use). In this case, under
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   certain conditions, the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   session cache can get into an incorrect state and it will
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   fail to flush properly
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   as it fills. The session cache will continue to grow in an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   unbounded manner. A
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   malicious client could deliberately create the scenario for
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   this failure to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   force a Denial of Service. It may also happen by accident in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    normal operation.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   This issue only affects TLS servers supporting TLSv1.3. It
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   does not affect TLS
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   clients.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   The FIPS modules in 3.2, 3.1 and 3.0 are not affected by
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   this issue. OpenSSL
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   1.0.2 is also not affected by this issue.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : openssl: Excessive time spent checking DSA keys and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   parameters 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Issue summary: Checking excessively long DSA keys or
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   parameters may be very
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   slow.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Impact summary: Applications that use the functions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   EVP_PKEY_param_check()
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   or EVP_PKEY_public_check() to check a DSA public key or DSA
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   parameters may
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   experience long delays. Where the key or parameters that are
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    being checked
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   have been obtained from an untrusted source this may lead to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    a Denial of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Service.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   The functions EVP_PKEY_param_check() or
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   EVP_PKEY_public_check() perform
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   various checks on DSA parameters. Some of those computations
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    take a long time
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   if the modulus (`p` parameter) is too large.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Trying to use a very large modulus is slow and OpenSSL will
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   not allow using
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   public keys with a modulus which is over 10,000 bits in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   length for signature
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   verification. However the key and parameter check functions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   do not limit
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   the modulus size when performing the checks.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   An application that calls EVP_PKEY_param_check() or
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   EVP_PKEY_public_check()
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   and supplies a key or parameters obtained from an untrusted
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   source could be
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   vulnerable to a Denial of Service attack.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   These functions are not called by OpenSSL itself on
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   untrusted DSA keys so
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   only applications that directly call these functions may be
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   vulnerable.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Also vulnerable are the OpenSSL pkey and pkeyparam command
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   line applications
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   when using the `-check` option.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   The OpenSSL SSL/TLS implementation is not affected by this
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   issue.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   The OpenSSL 3.0 and 3.1 FIPS providers are affected by this
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   issue.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : shadow: Improper input validation in shadow-utils
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   package utility chfn 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : In Shadow 4.13, it is possible to inject control
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   characters into fields provided to the SUID program chfn
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   (change finger). Although it is not possible to exploit this
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    directly (e.g., adding a new user fails because \n is in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   the block list), it is possible to misrepresent the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   /etc/passwd file when viewed. Use of \r manipulations and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Unicode characters to work around blocking of the :
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   character make it possible to give the impression that a new
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    user has been added. In other words, an adversary may be

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : The Diffie-Hellman Key Agreement Protocol allows use of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    long exponents that arguably make certain calculations
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   unnecessarily expensive, because the 1996 van Oorschot and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Wiener paper found that "(appropriately) short exponents"
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   can be used when there are adequate subgroup constraints,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   and these short exponents can lead to less expensive
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   calculations than for long exponents. This issue is
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   different from CVE-2002-20001 because it is based on an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   observation about exponent size, rather than an observation
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   about numbers that are not public keys. The specific
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   situations in which calculation expense would constitute a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   server-side vulnerability depend on the protocol (e.g., TLS,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    SSH, or IKE) and the DHE implementation details. In
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   general, there might be an availability concern because of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   server-side resource consumption from DHE
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   modular-exponentiation calculations. Finally, it is possible
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    for an attacker to exploit this vulnerability and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   CVE-2002-20001 together.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : openssl: Unbounded memory growth with session handling
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   in TLSv1.3 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Issue summary: Some non-default TLS server
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   configurations can cause unbounded
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   memory growth when processing TLSv1.3 sessions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Impact summary: An attacker may exploit certain server
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   configurations to trigger
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   unbounded memory growth that would lead to a Denial of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Service
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   This problem can occur in TLSv1.3 if the non-default
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   SSL_OP_NO_TICKET option is
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   being used (but not if early_data support is also configured
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    and the default
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   anti-replay protection is in use). In this case, under
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   certain conditions, the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   session cache can get into an incorrect state and it will
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   fail to flush properly
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   as it fills. The session cache will continue to grow in an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   unbounded manner. A
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   malicious client could deliberately create the scenario for
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   this failure to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   force a Denial of Service. It may also happen by accident in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    normal operation.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   This issue only affects TLS servers supporting TLSv1.3. It
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   does not affect TLS
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   clients.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   The FIPS modules in 3.2, 3.1 and 3.0 are not affected by
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   this issue. OpenSSL
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   1.0.2 is also not affected by this issue.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : openssl: Excessive time spent checking DSA keys and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   parameters 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Issue summary: Checking excessively long DSA keys or
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   parameters may be very
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   slow.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Impact summary: Applications that use the functions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   EVP_PKEY_param_check()
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   or EVP_PKEY_public_check() to check a DSA public key or DSA
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   parameters may
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   experience long delays. Where the key or parameters that are
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    being checked
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   have been obtained from an untrusted source this may lead to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    a Denial of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Service.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   The functions EVP_PKEY_param_check() or
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   EVP_PKEY_public_check() perform
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   various checks on DSA parameters. Some of those computations
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    take a long time
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   if the modulus (`p` parameter) is too large.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Trying to use a very large modulus is slow and OpenSSL will
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   not allow using
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   public keys with a modulus which is over 10,000 bits in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   length for signature
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   verification. However the key and parameter check functions
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   do not limit
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   the modulus size when performing the checks.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   An application that calls EVP_PKEY_param_check() or
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   EVP_PKEY_public_check()
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   and supplies a key or parameters obtained from an untrusted
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   source could be
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   vulnerable to a Denial of Service attack.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   These functions are not called by OpenSSL itself on
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   untrusted DSA keys so
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   only applications that directly call these functions may be
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   vulnerable.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Also vulnerable are the OpenSSL pkey and pkeyparam command
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   line applications
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   when using the `-check` option.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   The OpenSSL SSL/TLS implementation is not affected by this
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   issue.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   The OpenSSL 3.0 and 3.1 FIPS providers are affected by this
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   issue.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : shadow: Improper input validation in shadow-utils
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   package utility chfn 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : In Shadow 4.13, it is possible to inject control
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   characters into fields provided to the SUID program chfn
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   (change finger). Although it is not possible to exploit this
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    directly (e.g., adding a new user fails because \n is in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   the block list), it is possible to misrepresent the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   /etc/passwd file when viewed. Use of \r manipulations and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Unicode characters to work around blocking of the :
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   character make it possible to give the impression that a new
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    user has been added. In other words, an adversary may be
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   able to convince a system administrator to take the system
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   offline (an indirect, social-engineered denial of service)
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   by demonstrating that "cat /etc/passwd" shows a rogue user
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   account.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   can bypass a protection mechanism in which application
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   access is granted only after verifying receipt of e-mail to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   a specific domain (e.g., only @company.example.com addresses
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    may be used for signup). This occurs in email/_parseaddr.py

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : shadow: Improper input validation in shadow-utils
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   package utility chfn 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : In Shadow 4.13, it is possible to inject control
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   characters into fields provided to the SUID program chfn
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   (change finger). Although it is not possible to exploit this
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    directly (e.g., adding a new user fails because \n is in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   the block list), it is possible to misrepresent the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   /etc/passwd file when viewed. Use of \r manipulations and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Unicode characters to work around blocking of the :
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   character make it possible to give the impression that a new
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    user has been added. In other words, an adversary may be
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   able to convince a system administrator to take the system
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   offline (an indirect, social-engineered denial of service)
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   by demonstrating that "cat /etc/passwd" shows a rogue user
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   account.

â”‚                             â”œ Title           : jsoup: The jsoup cleaner may incorrectly sanitize
â”‚                             â”‚                   crafted XSS attempts if SafeList.preserveRelativeLinks is
â”‚                             â”‚                   enabled 
â”‚                             â”œ Description     : jsoup is a Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing,
â”‚                             â”‚                   cleaning, scraping, and cross-site scripting (XSS) safety.
â”‚                             â”‚                   jsoup may incorrectly sanitize HTML including `javascript:`
â”‚                             â”‚                   URL expressions, which could allow XSS attacks when a reader
â”‚                             â”‚                   subsequently clicks that link. If the non-default
â”‚                             â”‚                   `SafeList.preserveRelativeLinks` option is enabled, HTML
â”‚                             â”‚                   including `javascript:` URLs that have been crafted with
â”‚                             â”‚                   control characters will not be sanitized. If the site that
â”‚                             â”‚                   this HTML is published on does not set a Content Security
â”‚                             â”‚                   Policy, an XSS attack is then possible. This issue is patched
â”‚                             â”‚                    in jsoup 1.15.3. Users should upgrade to this version.
â”‚                             â”‚                   Additionally, as the unsanitized input may have been
â”‚                             â”‚                   persisted, old content should be cleaned again using the
â”‚                             â”‚                   updated version. To remediate this issue without immediately
â”‚                             â”‚                   upgrading: - disable `SafeList.preserveRelativeLinks`, which
â”‚                             â”‚                   will rewrite input URLs as absolute URLs - ensure an
â”‚                             â”‚                   appropriate [Content Security
â”‚                             â”‚                   Policy](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CSP
â”‚                             â”‚                   ) is defined. (This should be used regardless of upgrading,
â”‚                             â”‚                   as a defence-in-depth best practice.)

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: rapid stream resets can
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   cause excessive work (CVE-2023-44487) 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : A malicious HTTP/2 client which rapidly creates
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   requests and immediately resets them can cause excessive
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   server resource consumption. While the total number of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   requests is bounded by the http2.Server.MaxConcurrentStreams
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    setting, resetting an in-progress request allows the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   attacker to create a new request while the existing one is
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   still executing. With the fix applied, HTTP/2 servers now
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   bound the number of simultaneously executing handler
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   goroutines to the stream concurrency limit
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   (MaxConcurrentStreams). New requests arriving when at the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   limit (which can only happen after the client has reset an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   existing, in-flight request) will be queued until a handler
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   exits. If the request queue grows too large, the server will
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    terminate the connection. This issue is also fixed in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   golang.org/x/net/http2 for users manually configuring
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   HTTP/2. The default stream concurrency limit is 250 streams
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   (requests) per HTTP/2 connection. This value may be adjusted
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    using the golang.org/x/net/http2 package; see the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting and the ConfigureServer
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   function.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: unlimited number of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   CONTINUATION frames causes DoS 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : An attacker may cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary amounts of header data by sending an excessive
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   number of CONTINUATION frames. Maintaining HPACK state
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   requires parsing and processing all HEADERS and CONTINUATION
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    frames on a connection. When a request's headers exceed
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   MaxHeaderBytes, no memory is allocated to store the excess
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   headers, but they are still parsed. This permits an attacker
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    to cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read arbitrary amounts of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   header data, all associated with a request which is going to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    be rejected. These headers can include Huffman-encoded data
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    which is significantly more expensive for the receiver to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   decode than for an attacker to send. The fix sets a limit on
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    the amount of excess header frames we will process before
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   closing a connection.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: rapid stream resets can
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   cause excessive work (CVE-2023-44487) 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : A malicious HTTP/2 client which rapidly creates
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   requests and immediately resets them can cause excessive
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   server resource consumption. While the total number of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   requests is bounded by the http2.Server.MaxConcurrentStreams
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    setting, resetting an in-progress request allows the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   attacker to create a new request while the existing one is
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   still executing. With the fix applied, HTTP/2 servers now
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   bound the number of simultaneously executing handler
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   goroutines to the stream concurrency limit
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   (MaxConcurrentStreams). New requests arriving when at the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   limit (which can only happen after the client has reset an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   existing, in-flight request) will be queued until a handler
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   exits. If the request queue grows too large, the server will
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    terminate the connection. This issue is also fixed in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   golang.org/x/net/http2 for users manually configuring
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   HTTP/2. The default stream concurrency limit is 250 streams
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   (requests) per HTTP/2 connection. This value may be adjusted
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    using the golang.org/x/net/http2 package; see the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting and the ConfigureServer
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   function.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : The filepath package does not recognize paths with a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   \??\ prefix as sp ... 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : The filepath package does not recognize paths with a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   \??\ prefix as special. On Windows, a path beginning with
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   \??\ is a Root Local Device path equivalent to a path
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   beginning with \\?\. Paths with a \??\ prefix may be used to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    access arbitrary locations on the system. For example, the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   path \??\c:\x is equivalent to the more common path c:\x.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Before fix, Clean could convert a rooted path such as
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   \a\..\??\b into the root local device path \??\b. Clean will
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    now convert this to .\??\b. Similarly, Join(\, ??, b) could
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    convert a seemingly innocent sequence of path elements into
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    the root local device path \??\b. Join will now convert
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   this to \.\??\b. In addition, with fix, IsAbs now correctly
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   reports paths beginning with \??\ as absolute, and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   VolumeName correctly reports the \??\ prefix as a volume
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   name. UPDATE: Go 1.20.11 and Go 1.21.4 inadvertently changed
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    the definition of the volume name in Windows paths starting
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    with \?, resulting in filepath.Clean(\?\c:) returning \?\c:
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    rather than \?\c:\ (among other effects). The previous
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   behavior has been restored.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: unlimited number of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   CONTINUATION frames causes DoS 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : An attacker may cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary amounts of header data by sending an excessive
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   number of CONTINUATION frames. Maintaining HPACK state
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   requires parsing and processing all HEADERS and CONTINUATION
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    frames on a connection. When a request's headers exceed
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   MaxHeaderBytes, no memory is allocated to store the excess
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   headers, but they are still parsed. This permits an attacker
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    to cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read arbitrary amounts of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   header data, all associated with a request which is going to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    be rejected. These headers can include Huffman-encoded data
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    which is significantly more expensive for the receiver to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   decode than for an attacker to send. The fix sets a limit on
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    the amount of excess header frames we will process before
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   closing a connection.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http: insufficient sanitization of Host header 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : The HTTP/1 client does not fully validate the contents
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   of the Host header. A maliciously crafted Host header can
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   inject additional headers or entire requests. With fix, the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   HTTP/1 client now refuses to send requests containing an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   invalid Request.Host or Request.URL.Host value.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: crypto/tls: slow verification of certificate
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   chains containing large RSA keys 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Extremely large RSA keys in certificate chains can
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   cause a client/server to expend significant CPU time
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   verifying signatures. With fix, the size of RSA keys
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   transmitted during handshakes is restricted to <= 8192 bits.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    Based on a survey of publicly trusted RSA keys, there are
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   currently only three certificates in circulation with keys
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   larger than this, and all three appear to be test
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   certificates that are not actively deployed. It is possible
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   there are larger keys in use in private PKIs, but we target
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   the web PKI, so causing breakage here in the interests of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   increasing the default safety of users of crypto/tls seems
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   reasonable.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http/internal: Denial of Service (DoS) via
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Resource Consumption via HTTP requests 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : A malicious HTTP sender can use chunk extensions to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   cause a receiver reading from a request or response body to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   read many more bytes from the network than are in the body.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   A malicious HTTP client can further exploit this to cause a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   server to automatically read a large amount of data (up to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   about 1GiB) when a handler fails to read the entire body of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   a request. Chunk extensions are a little-used HTTP feature
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   which permit including additional metadata in a request or
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   response body sent using the chunked encoding. The net/http
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   chunked encoding reader discards this metadata. A sender can
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    exploit this by inserting a large metadata segment with
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   each byte transferred. The chunk reader now produces an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   error if the ratio of real body to encoded bytes grows too
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   small.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : On Windows, The IsLocal function does not correctly
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   detect reserved device names in some cases. Reserved names
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   followed by spaces, such as "COM1 ", and reserved names
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   "COM" and "LPT" followed by superscript 1, 2, or 3, are
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   incorrectly reported as local. With fix, IsLocal now
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   correctly reports these names as non-local.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http/cookiejar: incorrect forwarding of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   sensitive headers and cookies on HTTP redirect 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : When following an HTTP redirect to a domain which is
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   not a subdomain match or exact match of the initial domain,

â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   "Authorization" or "Cookie". For example, a redirect from
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   foo.com to www.foo.com will forward the Authorization
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   header, but a redirect to bar.com will not. A maliciously

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http: memory exhaustion in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Request.ParseMultipartForm 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : When parsing a multipart form (either explicitly with
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Request.ParseMultipartForm or implicitly with
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Request.FormValue, Request.PostFormValue, or
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Request.FormFile), limits on the total size of the parsed
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   form were not applied to the memory consumed while reading a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    single form line. This permits a maliciously crafted input
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   containing very long lines to cause allocation of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrarily large amounts of memory, potentially leading to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   memory exhaustion. With fix, the ParseMultipartForm function
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    now correctly limits the maximum size of form
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   lines.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: rapid stream resets can
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   cause excessive work (CVE-2023-44487) 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : A malicious HTTP/2 client which rapidly creates
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   requests and immediately resets them can cause excessive
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   server resource consumption. While the total number of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   requests is bounded by the http2.Server.MaxConcurrentStreams
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    setting, resetting an in-progress request allows the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   attacker to create a new request while the existing one is
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   still executing. With the fix applied, HTTP/2 servers now
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   bound the number of simultaneously executing handler
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   goroutines to the stream concurrency limit
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   (MaxConcurrentStreams). New requests arriving when at the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   limit (which can only happen after the client has reset an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   existing, in-flight request) will be queued until a handler
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   exits. If the request queue grows too large, the server will
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    terminate the connection. This issue is also fixed in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   golang.org/x/net/http2 for users manually configuring
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   HTTP/2. The default stream concurrency limit is 250 streams
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   (requests) per HTTP/2 connection. This value may be adjusted
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    using the golang.org/x/net/http2 package; see the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting and the ConfigureServer
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   function.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: unlimited number of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   CONTINUATION frames causes DoS 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : An attacker may cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary amounts of header data by sending an excessive
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   number of CONTINUATION frames. Maintaining HPACK state
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   requires parsing and processing all HEADERS and CONTINUATION
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    frames on a connection. When a request's headers exceed
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   MaxHeaderBytes, no memory is allocated to store the excess
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   headers, but they are still parsed. This permits an attacker
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    to cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read arbitrary amounts of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   header data, all associated with a request which is going to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    be rejected. These headers can include Huffman-encoded data
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    which is significantly more expensive for the receiver to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   decode than for an attacker to send. The fix sets a limit on
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    the amount of excess header frames we will process before
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   closing a connection.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: rapid stream resets can
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   cause excessive work (CVE-2023-44487) 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : A malicious HTTP/2 client which rapidly creates
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   requests and immediately resets them can cause excessive
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   server resource consumption. While the total number of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   requests is bounded by the http2.Server.MaxConcurrentStreams
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    setting, resetting an in-progress request allows the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   attacker to create a new request while the existing one is
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   still executing. With the fix applied, HTTP/2 servers now
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   bound the number of simultaneously executing handler
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   goroutines to the stream concurrency limit
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   (MaxConcurrentStreams). New requests arriving when at the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   limit (which can only happen after the client has reset an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   existing, in-flight request) will be queued until a handler
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   exits. If the request queue grows too large, the server will
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    terminate the connection. This issue is also fixed in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   golang.org/x/net/http2 for users manually configuring
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   HTTP/2. The default stream concurrency limit is 250 streams
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   (requests) per HTTP/2 connection. This value may be adjusted
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    using the golang.org/x/net/http2 package; see the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting and the ConfigureServer
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   function.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : The filepath package does not recognize paths with a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   \??\ prefix as sp ... 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : The filepath package does not recognize paths with a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   \??\ prefix as special. On Windows, a path beginning with
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   \??\ is a Root Local Device path equivalent to a path
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   beginning with \\?\. Paths with a \??\ prefix may be used to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    access arbitrary locations on the system. For example, the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   path \??\c:\x is equivalent to the more common path c:\x.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Before fix, Clean could convert a rooted path such as
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   \a\..\??\b into the root local device path \??\b. Clean will
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    now convert this to .\??\b. Similarly, Join(\, ??, b) could
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    convert a seemingly innocent sequence of path elements into
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    the root local device path \??\b. Join will now convert
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   this to \.\??\b. In addition, with fix, IsAbs now correctly
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   reports paths beginning with \??\ as absolute, and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   VolumeName correctly reports the \??\ prefix as a volume
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   name. UPDATE: Go 1.20.11 and Go 1.21.4 inadvertently changed
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    the definition of the volume name in Windows paths starting
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    with \?, resulting in filepath.Clean(\?\c:) returning \?\c:
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    rather than \?\c:\ (among other effects). The previous
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   behavior has been restored.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: unlimited number of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   CONTINUATION frames causes DoS 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : An attacker may cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary amounts of header data by sending an excessive
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   number of CONTINUATION frames. Maintaining HPACK state
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   requires parsing and processing all HEADERS and CONTINUATION
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    frames on a connection. When a request's headers exceed
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   MaxHeaderBytes, no memory is allocated to store the excess
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   headers, but they are still parsed. This permits an attacker
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    to cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read arbitrary amounts of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   header data, all associated with a request which is going to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    be rejected. These headers can include Huffman-encoded data
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    which is significantly more expensive for the receiver to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   decode than for an attacker to send. The fix sets a limit on
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    the amount of excess header frames we will process before
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   closing a connection.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http: insufficient sanitization of Host header 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : The HTTP/1 client does not fully validate the contents
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   of the Host header. A maliciously crafted Host header can
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   inject additional headers or entire requests. With fix, the
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   HTTP/1 client now refuses to send requests containing an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   invalid Request.Host or Request.URL.Host value.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: crypto/tls: slow verification of certificate
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   chains containing large RSA keys 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : Extremely large RSA keys in certificate chains can
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   cause a client/server to expend significant CPU time
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   verifying signatures. With fix, the size of RSA keys
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   transmitted during handshakes is restricted to <= 8192 bits.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    Based on a survey of publicly trusted RSA keys, there are
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   currently only three certificates in circulation with keys
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   larger than this, and all three appear to be test
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   certificates that are not actively deployed. It is possible
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   there are larger keys in use in private PKIs, but we target
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   the web PKI, so causing breakage here in the interests of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   increasing the default safety of users of crypto/tls seems
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   reasonable.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: html/template: improper handling of special
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   tags within script contexts 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : The html/template package does not apply the proper
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   rules for handling occurrences of "<script", "<!--", and
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   "</script" within JS literals in <script> contexts. This may
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    cause the template parser to improperly consider script
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   contexts to be terminated early, causing actions to be
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   improperly escaped. This could be leveraged to perform an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   XSS attack.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http/internal: Denial of Service (DoS) via
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Resource Consumption via HTTP requests 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : A malicious HTTP sender can use chunk extensions to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   cause a receiver reading from a request or response body to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   read many more bytes from the network than are in the body.
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   A malicious HTTP client can further exploit this to cause a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   server to automatically read a large amount of data (up to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   about 1GiB) when a handler fails to read the entire body of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   a request. Chunk extensions are a little-used HTTP feature
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   which permit including additional metadata in a request or
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   response body sent using the chunked encoding. The net/http
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   chunked encoding reader discards this metadata. A sender can
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    exploit this by inserting a large metadata segment with
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   each byte transferred. The chunk reader now produces an
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   error if the ratio of real body to encoded bytes grows too
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   small.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   detect reserved device names in some cases. Reserved names
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   followed by spaces, such as "COM1 ", and reserved names
