â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http/cookiejar: incorrect forwarding of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   sensitive headers and cookies on HTTP redirect 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : When following an HTTP redirect to a domain which is
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   not a subdomain match or exact match of the initial domain,
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   an http.Client does not forward sensitive headers such as
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   "Authorization" or "Cookie". For example, a redirect from
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   foo.com to www.foo.com will forward the Authorization
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   header, but a redirect to bar.com will not. A maliciously
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   crafted HTTP redirect could cause sensitive headers to be
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   unexpectedly forwarded.

â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http: memory exhaustion in
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Request.ParseMultipartForm 
â”‚                       â”‚      â”œ Description     : When parsing a multipart form (either explicitly with
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Request.ParseMultipartForm or implicitly with
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Request.FormValue, Request.PostFormValue, or
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   Request.FormFile), limits on the total size of the parsed
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   form were not applied to the memory consumed while reading a
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    single form line. This permits a maliciously crafted input
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   containing very long lines to cause allocation of
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrarily large amounts of memory, potentially leading to
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   memory exhaustion. With fix, the ParseMultipartForm function
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                    now correctly limits the maximum size of form
â”‚                       â”‚      â”‚                   lines.

â”‚                       â”‚     â”œ Title           : moby: IPv6 enabled on IPv4-only network interfaces 
â”‚                       â”‚     â”œ Description     : Moby is an open source container framework that is a key
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                    component of Docker Engine, Docker Desktop, and other
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   distributions of container tooling or runtimes. In 26.0.0,
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   IPv6 is not disabled on network interfaces, including those
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   belonging to networks where `--ipv6=false`. An container with
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                    an `ipvlan` or `macvlan` interface will normally be
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   configured to share an external network link with the host
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   machine. Because of this direct access, (1) Containers may be
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                    able to communicate with other hosts on the local network
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   over link-local IPv6 addresses, (2) if router advertisements
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   are being broadcast over the local network, containers may
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   get SLAAC-assigned addresses, and (3) the interface  will be
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   a member of IPv6 multicast groups. This means interfaces in
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   IPv4-only networks present an unexpectedly and unnecessarily
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   increased attack surface. The issue is patched in 26.0.2. To
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   completely disable IPv6 in a container, use
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   `--sysctl=net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6=1` in the `docker
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   create` or `docker run` command. Or, in the service
â”‚                       â”‚     â”‚                   configuration of a `compose` file.
